ContentClassification.TableReference: National Association of Insurance Commissioners, "1985 NAIC Cancer Claim Cost Tables", Proceedings of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, Vol. I. (Kansas City, Mo. 1986)
ContentClassification.TableName: 1985 NAIC Cancer Claim Cost Table First Occurrence Benefit - Male
ContentClassification.TableDescription: 1985 National Association of Insurance Commissioners (NAIC) Cancer Claim Cost Table – Male. Basis: First Occurrence Benefit (Per $100 Benefit). Minimum Attained Age: 15. Maximum Attained Age: 99
ContentClassification.Comments: Study Data: Based on lives insured under cancer expense policies. Claim information includes payments during 1978 and 1979. It is believed 80% of all applicable experience is included in the study. First occurrence claim costs are considered appropriate for valuing lump sum benefits for first occurrence of internal cancers. When a covered individual is diagnosed with cancer, benefits may be provided for hospital confinement, radiation, chemotherapy and surgery, among others. A cancer policy also helps by providing benefits to help with the many non-medical expenses associated with cancer (See SOA Table identities 1460-1475, 1483-1485, and 2587-2596). Benefits may be paid as expense incurred, per diem or a lump sum. Cancer policies may also pay an optional Initial Diagnosis benefit or First Occurrence benefit when a covered individual is first diagnosed as having internal cancer. This table represents the costs associated with the latter. Methodology: Not available at this time. Data Transcription Errors: None. Data Certified: 12/2012.

MetaData.TableDescription: 1985 National Association of Insurance Commissioners (NAIC) Cancer Claim Cost Table – Male. Basis: First Occurrence Benefit (Per $100 Benefit). Minimum Attained Age: 15. Maximum Attained Age: 99
